title: Member Spotlight: Innovation in Careers Education at University of Leeds
summary: Discover how the University of Leeds Careers Centre has implemented a cutting-edge peer mentoring programme that's transforming student engagement.
content:
In our latest member spotlight, we speak with Sarah Thompson, Director of Careers at the University of Leeds, about their innovative peer mentoring initiative.

Launched in September 2024, the programme pairs final-year students with first and second-year students to provide authentic career insights and guidance.

Results have been impressive: 92% of participants reported increased confidence in their career planning, and engagement with careers services has risen by 35%.

The Leeds team will be presenting their approach at the Annual Conference in June.

title: New Research: Impact of AI on Graduate Recruitment
summary: Our latest research explores how artificial intelligence is transforming the graduate recruitment landscape and what it means for careers services.
content:
AGCAS has published groundbreaking research examining the role of AI in graduate recruitment processes.

The study, conducted over 12 months with participation from 50+ universities, reveals significant trends in how employers are adopting AI tools for screening, assessment, and candidate engagement.

Key findings include a 45% increase in AI-powered application screening and emerging concerns about algorithmic bias.

content:

title: Our response to the Post-16 Education and Skills White Paper
summary: Our response to the Post-16 Education and Skills White Paper
content:
Following the publication of the Post-16 Education and Skills White Paper, Martin Edmondson, Chief Executive of the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services (AGCAS) said: 


“We welcome the Government’s recognition of the huge potential of our universities to drive economic growth, deliver a pipeline of critical skills, and break down barriers to opportunity. Demand for higher-level skills is only set to grow, and we support the ambition for universities to play an even greater role in meeting the local and regional skills needs that underpin the UK’s economic success. 


“As we tackle global challenges and embrace rapid technological change, higher education has a central role in equipping people with the skills, adaptability, and innovation needed for the future. To achieve this, high-quality careers guidance and work-integrated learning must feature throughout the student journey, ensuring opportunities are open to people from all backgrounds and career stages. 


“University careers and employability teams are critical to this mission. Their professional expertise should be at the heart of shaping institutional strategy on employability, supported by adequate resourcing and close collaboration with academic colleagues. Employability strategies that combine professional insight with academic specialism are vital to producing graduates ready to thrive in the modern economy. Employability experts are also vital in building local partnerships to ensure that regions develop the right mix of skills pipelines. 


“Across the sector, universities are already making great strides in this space. We see this demonstrated in the achievements recognised through our annual Academic Employability Awards. These examples showcase what’s possible when institutions invest in employability, actively develop skills in curriculum, collaborate with employers, and empower their students to connect learning with real-world opportunities.”

title: AGCAS response to the Department for Business and Trade consultation on unpaid internships
summary: Our response to the Department for Business and Trade consultation on Making Work Pay: unpaid internships
content:
We recently responded to the Department for Business and Trade consultation on Making Work Pay: unpaid internships. You can find the full response here, but in summary we welcome the Government’s focus on fair and inclusive work experience. We strongly support payment for internships that are not part of an accredited course and call for clearer definitions, consistent terminology, and targeted reform of student placement rules.


The key points are:

  • Internships should be defined in legislation and paid at least the National Minimum Wage if not part of a course.
  • Transparency must be required: employers should state pay status and opportunity type in all adverts.
  • Short unpaid tasters may be appropriate only where truly observational, short in duration, and with informed consent.
  • Mandatory student placements should retain limited exemptions but with clearer boundaries and safeguards; nuanced reforms such as duration-based or apprenticeship-rate models are preferred to outright removal.
  • Volunteering and work shadowing should be clearly distinguished from internships to avoid legal ambiguity and visa risks.
  • Social mobility must be central: unpaid internships exclude those without financial means.
  • Government should improve guidance and enforcement, ensuring plain-English communications and better public understanding of rights.


Thanks to our members who helped shape our response to the consultation. We were also guided by the AGCAS Work Experience Standard, you can read here


We will be closely following government updates on this and will share the news with members as soon as we can.

title: AGCAS publish new Uncovering Skills report and announce launch webinar
summary: AGCAS are proud to launch our Uncovering Skills report today, supported by Symplicity.
content:
AGCAS are proud to launch our Uncovering Skills report today, supported by Symplicity.


With the recently published Post-16 Education and Skills White Paper recognising that high-quality careers guidance and work experience are crucial in harnessing the talents of young people from all backgrounds, this new report has brought timely and critical debate to this key area.


Drawing on three AGCAS datasets, national focus groups, and earlier research, this report highlights the importance of recognising the full range of skills students develop - beyond the academic setting - to help boost graduate employability. These insights are especially relevant for those who work with students and graduates who find it challenging to explain how their broader experiences connect to career readiness.
